title: Estimating the Hubble Constant with Type Ia Supernovae
text:
#| label: load-packages #| include: false
import pandas as pd import numpy as np import matplotlib.pyplot as plt import seaborn as sns
from sklearn.linear_model import LinearRegression from sklearn.preprocessing import PolynomialFeatures from sklearn.metrics import mean_squared_error, mean_absolute_error, r2_score
sns.set_theme(style=“whitegrid”) sns.set_context(“notebook”, font_scale=1.1)
plt.rcParams[‘figure.dpi’] = 300 plt.rcParams[‘savefig.dpi’] = 300 plt.rcParams[‘figure.figsize’] = (6, 6 * 0.618)
#| label: load-data #| include: false
df = pd.read_csv(“../data/processed/clean_sn_data.csv”)
X = df[[‘d_L_Mpc’]].values y = df[‘velocity_kms’].values

Linear model (global)
lin_model = LinearRegression() lin_model.fit(X, y) y_pred = lin_model.predict(X)
rmse_lin = np.sqrt(mean_squared_error(y, y_pred)) mae_lin = mean_absolute_error(y, y_pred) r2_lin = r2_score(y, y_pred)


Quadratic model (curvature test)
poly = PolynomialFeatures(degree=2, include_bias=False) X_poly = poly.fit_transform(X)
poly_model = LinearRegression() poly_model.fit(X_poly, y) y_poly_pred = poly_model.predict(X_poly)
rmse_poly = np.sqrt(mean_squared_error(y, y_poly_pred)) mae_poly = mean_absolute_error(y, y_poly_pred)

title: Estimating the Hubble Constant with Pantheon+ Supernovae
text:
Goal

Estimate the Hubble constant (H₀) using Pantheon+ supernova data
Evaluate whether a simple linear Hubble Law fits well

title: Estimating the Hubble Constant with Pantheon+ Supernovae
text:
Data

Dataset: Pantheon+ supernovae (distance vs recessional velocity / redshift-based velocity)
Key variables used: distance and velocity (with any filtering/cleaning described in EDA)

title: Estimating the Hubble Constant with Pantheon+ Supernovae
text:
Approach

Baseline model: linear regression (v = H₀ d)
Check fit: residual patterns vs distance
Compare: linear vs quadratic (as a diagnostic, not expected physically at low z)

title: Estimating the Hubble Constant with Pantheon+ Supernovae
text:
Key Results

Linear model: R² = 0.983, RMSE = 711 km/s
Estimated H₀ = 64 km/s/Mpc
Main takeaway:

title: Estimating the Hubble Constant with Pantheon+ Supernovae
text:
Hubble Diagram





Strong linear relationship between distance and velocity
Scatter increases at larger distances

title: Estimating the Hubble Constant with Pantheon+ Supernovae
text:
Model Performance

Linear model fit:

R² ≈ 0.98
RMSE ≈ 711 km/s

Estimated Hubble constant:

H₀ ≈ 65–67 km/s/Mpc

title: Estimating the Hubble Constant with Pantheon+ Supernovae
text:
Model Comparison

Linear regression provides a strong baseline fit
Quadratic model increased error (higher RMSE)
Added curvature does not improve predictive performance

title: Estimating the Hubble Constant with Pantheon+ Supernovae
text:
Residuals & Interpretation

Residuals increase slightly with distance
Pattern suggests growing observational uncertainty at large distances
No strong evidence that a nonlinear model is required

title: Estimating the Hubble Constant with Pantheon+ Supernovae
text:
Main Takeaway

Hubble’s Law provides an excellent first-order description of the data
Linear regression yields a stable estimate of H₀
More complex models do not improve performance for this dataset
